description: Origin obscure. Possibly a metathesis of gutter.

entries.meaning: (mining) A gutter or channel for water, hewn out of the bottom of a working drift.

description: From Middle English girt, gert, a metathetic variant of gret (“great”). More at great.

entries.meaning: (UK dialect, West Country) Pronunciation spelling of great.
examples: Then I opens the cupboard door and I sees a gurt big spider looking up at me.
